review.title: Explaining robust additive utility models by sequences of preference swaps
review.abstract: Multicriteria decision analysis aims at supporting a person facing a decision problem involving conflicting criteria. We consider an additive utility model which provides robust conclusions based on preferences elicited from the decision maker. The recommendations based on these robust conclusions are even more convincing if they are complemented by explanations. We propose a general scheme, based on sequence of preference swaps, in which explanations can be computed. We show first that the length of explanations can be unbounded in the general case. However, in the case of binary reference scales, this length is bounded and we provide an algorithm to compute the corresponding explanation.

sections.text: ar Xiv: 150 2.04 593v 1Multi-criterion decision analysis aims to support a person who is faced with a decision problem involving conflicting criteria. We consider an additive use model that provides robust conclusions based on preferences elicited from the decision maker. The recommendations based on these robust conclusions are all the more convincing when supplemented by explanations. We propose a general scheme based on the sequence of preferential swaps in which explanations can be calculated. We first show that the length of explanations can generally be unlimited, but in the case of binary reference scales this length is limited and we provide an algorithm for calculating the corresponding explanation.

sections.heading: 4 Explanation Engine
sections.text: We remember that our decision-making model is based on a robust additive utility model (see Section 2). A simple way of explaining it would use the calculated utility functions and issue them to the decision-maker. The difficulty of this approach is two-fold: First, commodities are fundamentally not normalized because they provide values on different scales, so it is not always easy to interpret them. A simple way to solve this problem is to impose the extreme values on each attribute, which is the fact that valuations can be compared on different criteria. More specifically, criteria should not be met at all for each minimal element of the attributes, and criteria should be fully met for each maximum element of the attributes, which amounts to transforming the additive utility model into a weighted sum in which the commodities are normalized and each criterion is assigned a weight.
